clinical_study.brief_title: Myocardial Perfusion Study to Detect Coronary Microvascular Abnormality in Diabetic Patients With Nonfatal Myocardial Infarction
clinical_study.official_title: Myocardial Perfusion Study to Detect Coronary Microvascular Abnormality in Diabetic Patients With Nonfatal Myocardial Infarction

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York - Upstate Medical University

clinical_study.source: State University of New York - Upstate Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to use MCE (myocardial contrast/perfusion echocardiography) to study and compare short/long term change of myocardial perfusion abnormality and cardiac outcome in diabetic patients after nonfatal MI (heart attack), who are treated with different glucose control agents.

primary_outcome.measure: Perfusion abnormalities in nondiabetic and diabetic patients
primary_outcome.time_frame: short term (3 month) and long term (12 month).

secondary_outcome.measure: The effect of different glycemic control strategies on the reduction of coronary injury in diabetic and non-diabetic subjects
secondary_outcome.time_frame: short term (3 month) and long term (12 month)

study_pop.textblock: Diabetic and nondiabetic patients will be initially recruited and studied after acute nonfatal MI and revascularization with either PCI or CABG

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diabetic and nondiabetic patients will be initially recruited and studied after acute nonfatal MI and revascularization with either PCI or CABG
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients are excluded if they are older than 70 year old, require mechanical ventilation, are receiving intravenous pressors or hemodynamic support, or if the motion of segments associated with infarct-related artery can not be accurately determined.
